text: Tap @Mikkeller Viktoriagade. 2015 edition. Pours deep opaque black with a small, staying creamy beige head. Aroma has sweet malts, light roasted, plenty chocolate, mild nuts, actually kinda soft coffee. Light vinious. Medium to low carbonation, fine dry and quite creamy mouthfeel. Flavour has soft coffee, light vinious, some roasted astringency, tar. Lingering warmth with some solid coffee-like bitterness.

On tap at Mikkeller Bar. Murky brown color with brownish head. Aroma has roasted malt, vanilla and coffee. Taste has dark chocolate, cacao, acidic malt. Quite dry and astringent finish. Quite different from the last time I had it.

2014 A: Pitch black with a nice two finger light brown head N: Coffee, bitter chocolate, hint of plum and rye bread T: Coffee, plum, bitter chocolate, milk chocolate, hint of liqourice O: Very nice and still complex coffee flavours. NICE!

Draught drank w Masaki near South Bank book fair. Pours an opaque black-brown with creamy fizzy beige head. Lots of coffee, dark roast malt, light vanilla bean, some burnt/roast acidity in the taste where the nose has more bitterness, moderately herbal, dark chocolate, warming booze but surprisingly well hidden (12%!). Body is slick but very smooth, lightly sudsy faint lemon in the finish. Chocolate dark malt flavours balanced by plenty of coffee bitterness. Quite smooth/refined.
Tap @ tape. Aroma of coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malt. Black with tan head. Taste is moderate- sweet and light malt bitter. Full body, oily feel and roasted malt, chocolate coffee feel finish.

On tap at Mikkekker & Friends. Pitch black pour with a fine-grained tan head. Notes of roasted coffee, brewed coffee, toffee, molasses, chocolate. Smooth texture, creamy and lightly carbonated. Good stuff!
Black with a brown head - Dark malt and coffee aroma - Malt body with coffee flavour and bitterness - The malt and coffee with bitterness goes into the finish - This was real good

Keg at Beer Gonzo tap room. Pours jet black with dirty tan head. Aroma is coffee and chocolate, a little booze and coconut. Taste is coconut, chocolate and coffee with a little booze and cocoa on the end. Really nice stuff

First beer I¬íve sampled from the new tap room at Beer Gonzo. Ludicrously smooth, creamy mouth feel. Body starts off looking black but later resolves into dark brown with reddish hues. Nose very much coffee and chocolate. Taste brings in some licqorice and brown sugar too. Like the "standard" speedway, not packed with subtle surprises, but a luxurious take on coffee and roasted malts.

Yields a coal black color with a huge, creamy dark brown head.

Smells of sweet cold brew coffee, lots of milk chocolate and just a little hint of roast. Molasses and spicy licorice mingle into this foundation, producing a milk chocolate powder aroma.

Has a thinner, velvet mouthfeel, with flavors ranging from sweet to dry, without a lot of nuances in between, tied together by a lower carbonation. 

Tastes of rock sugar and hot chocolate, molasses, surprisingly thin on the palate, with a slowly evolving coffee dryness. Once the coffee takes over, this begins to taste interesting, bringing flavors of dried herbs, earth, wood bark and sugared espresso beans to the palate, pungent and harmonious. Finishes bitter, bready and rustic, with its initial silkness.

If it wasn¬ít for the thin mouthfeel, with just a little more complexity to it, the beer could become mighty fine. As it stands, there is quite a bit unused potential to be found in here.

Tasted from draft. Pours black with beige head. Aroma is robust coffee and some chocolate. Taste is moderately sweet with mild bitter finish. Flavors of coffee and dark chocolate. Very well done.

From the tap at FOB, Rimini, Italy. Pours practically black worth abundant cappuccino foam. Aroma is dominated by a sweet toffee feeling, but also dried figs. Body is medium-dense, with moderate stickiness. Taste is sweet at start, but some enjoyable bitterness and a little spiciness come up almost immediately. Finish is clean enough, with some bitterness persisting.

From backlog. Draught at Fermetoren. Black color, beige head. Bitter taste with roasted malts, nuts, coffee, vanilla, chocolate, dark fruits and a bit of licorice. Bitter finish with roasted malts, nuts, vanilla, dark fruits, chocolate, coffee and a bit of wood. Exquisite imperial stout.
Coffee, chocolate praline aroma and taste. Smooth, full bodied with low carbonation and pleasant warming. Truly, one of the best.

Pours black with light brown head. A coffee, cobalt, and roasted make aroma. A sweeter taste than other speedways with a sweet malt and caramel, but also coffee and chocolate. A sweet and roasted malt and coffee aftertaste.

Pitch black body, big brown head. Strong, sweet coffee aroma, heavy with mocha, cr√®me de cacao liqueur. Very heavy but incredibly smooth palate. Extraordinary flavour with sweet and bitter coffee, mocha, caramel, dark chocolate, toffee, hazelnut. Incredible.
Draft pours her black. Palate is thick and sticky. The taste is coffee. Sweetness at first. Vanilla chocolate and coffee. Awesome beer

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2016 Bottle, organized by SinH4, many thanks! The aroma hints at what the mouth feels: Chocolate. Much more sweet chocolate than the regular Speedway, especially on the tongue. Cocoa, vanilla, coconut. Aroma is a tad mellow, everything else about this beer is absolutely stellar.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2017 2016 Bottle, many thanks Max! Black color with beige head. Aroma is quite aromatic, molten chocolate, fresh espresso, with a hint of booze. Taste is viscous molten milk chocolate, espresso, vanilla, touch of coconut. Very silky mouthfeel. Absolutely amazing, but the aroma is just a bit too weak, else this would be completely over the top!Older bottle, thanks Koelschtrinker! Sweetish, not as full-bodied as fresh.

750ml bottle shared with Seb. Aroma: big deluxe coffee, light vanilla and light roasted malt. App: dark brown almost black with medium frothy moka head leaving big bubbly lacing. Taste and palate: full body, really really smooth, light roastiness and bitter finish coming from the coffee. Overall: damn good. That coffee is so good. Could drink that in the morning in camping. Amazing! Need more!

Intense aroma, with mainly lots of milk coffee, espresso and vanilla at first, over time more milk chocolate emerges. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and light bitter, of chocolate, milk coffee, vanilla, cocoa, with roasty notes in the finish and gentle alcohol warming. Full body, oily, creamy, smooth texture and soft carbonation. World class, delightful dessert of a beer!

Tap @Alebrowar Gdynia

Looks: Deep black with light brown thick short head 
Taste: Moderately sweet, intensively vanilla, especially in the finish. A lot of chocolate and coffee tastes mix with malty toffee. Very rich and multilayered. The alcohol is pretty well hidden.
Feel: It feels full but not yet oily. Carbonation is soft and medium strength
Overall: A great dessert beer. Multilayered and complex. Very interesting to drink. Would happily drink it again. And again. And again...

Draught at Copenhagen Beer Celebration 2015. Opaque black liquid with medium tan head. Aroma of coffee, licorice, raw sugar, espresso. Taste is light sweet and light to medium bitter with notes of coffee, licorice, light leather and espresso. Full bodied with medium carbonation. Great beer, great coffee notes.

From Notes-on tap at Growler,Madison wi-Dark black with little head. Smell of chocolate and coffee. Taste followed the nose. This was good not a coffee lover but had to try when I found out they had it.

On tap at Lunar Brewing Co., and snifter served to the brim, showing a ruby highlighted, black/brown hue, with a thin layer of creamy, brownish tan foam that dissipated quickly, leaving some ribbons & spots of lacing as the liquid pleasantly lowered. The nose was heavily roasted, espresso-like notes, with some tartness & tanginess, dark caramel & toffee sweetness, and some cocoa on the back. Medium to full bodied, the taste added a dry, roasted & earthy astringency that lingered into the finish, escorted by some complementary warmth. Fairly pricey pour, but can¬ít say I was disappointed.

On tap at the brewery. Generous 8 oz pour in a snifter. Let it warm a bit. Black with a thin lacy head. Slightly boozy chocolate coffee aromas. Huge flavors. Very rich with lots of layers. Well balanced. More toffee and dark stone fruit notes. Long coffee finish. Close to perfection.

Near black with a beige head. Nice lacing. Aroma is milk chocolate, cocoa, and coffee. Taste is predominantly milk and dark chocolate but also has a strong bitter acidic coffee note. Lingering coffee and chocolate aftertaste. Medium slick body.

Dark brown with thin ring of chocolate head. Aroma is interesting, with chocolate and chlorine, just like a swimming suit dried after a day at the pool. Taste only has mild booze, and plenty of chocolate. Not super complex, but it might just be that it¬ís served too cold. Let¬ís wait.... Warmer now, but still a bit thin and boozy. Not much coffee, would have liked more.

On tap at the Mule Bar, Winooski VT.
This was poured into a tulip.
The appearance was a dark brown almost black color. Quickly dissipating slim white head. Sticky rimmed/ringed lacing.
The aroma started off with a beautiful blend of the sweet to roasty coffee. Subtle vanilla. Smooth milk chocolate, and some dark chocolate. Some bitter coffee bean.
To my knowledge since I¬ím a bit uneducated on actual "Vietnamese coffee", there¬ís a nice grabbingly sweet to bitter coffee bean abounding over top of the milk and dark chocolate. Semi-smooth and somewhat sticky on the aftertaste to run into the finish.
On the palate, this one was about a medium on the body with a certain smoothness just impounding my tongue ever so lovely.
Overall, beautifully and wonderfully done imperial stout. I would love to have this again.

Thanks Matt for sharing the crowler! Poured into a snifter showing pitch black with a half a finger of latte colored foam. 

The nose shows a lot of notes of milk chocolate. 

The palate is thick and foamy with a moderate carbonation. Light sweetness throughout with flavors of milk chocolate throughout but ending on a clean harmonious black coffee bitterness. Fantastic.

On tap at Elizabeth Station. Pours an opaque dark brown with a dark beige head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, some fruity notes, pleasanant, but not very intense. Taste is chocolate, some spices, slightly boozy, but easy drinkable. Chocolate and coffee aftertaste. Very good.
Draft - Big sweet roast and choclate. Jet black with a rich brown head. Coffee, dark chocolate and a rich long finish. Solid, but not my favourite of the variants.

Tap at Logans. Black with one finger head. Wonderfully balanced, which seems especially difficult when coffee is involved. Light booze, dark chocolate, light caramel. Perfect amount coffee - just right. Super smooth.

I¬íd¬íve loved to see more caramel sweetness plus a condensed milk creaminess in this beer; that would¬íve been really true to the Vietnamese coffee style. Aroma: intense malt aroma with huge aroma of coffee ; fresh roasted coffee beans, best espresso coffee, dark chocolate, cacao nibs, hint of molasses, dark fruits in the background...flavor: very, very similar to aroma: intense, rich dark, roasted malts flavor, with notes, mentioned above. I¬ím a huge fan of all versions of Speedway stout, but still the regular version remains for my point of view the top one.

Crowler->snifter from Dominion, and draft->wine glass at B Side Merifield. Thanks to the tip from Donnie the Degenerate. Black with moderate thick khaki head. A: chicory, coffee chocolate malt, molasses. T: rich coffee, dark chocolate, slight booze, coffee. Rich and good.

Bottle. Opaque dark brown with a frothy/creamy brown head. Intense coffee and fruity aromas, hints of caramel, toffee, peanut butter, biscotti, vanilla, alcohol. Full bodied, moderate carbonation. Smooth, yet oily. Medium sweet, medium to heavy bitter. Complex and heavy. Exquisite roasted and coffee flavors into a harsh bitter finish.

Pours black with a medium frothy brown head that slowly fades to a thin cap and small ring. AROMA: dark rich malt, dark roasted coffee, dark bitter chocolate, roasty, spices, herbal hops, molasses, brown sugar, dark dry fruit, slight raisin, vanilla, smoke, herbs, earthy, boozy and slight peppercorn. TASTE: dark rich malt,dark roasted bitter coffee, dark bitter chocolate, roasty, spices, hop spice, molasses, brown sugar, soy sauce, dark dry fruit, slight raisin, vanilla, smoke, herbs, earthy, boozy and slight peppercorn. AFTER TASTE: rich roasty malt, chocolate, coffee, spices and hop resin with a medium thick boozy bitter finish.

Bottle, 650ml. A dark beer with minimal brown head. Deep aroma of coffee, dried fruits, malt and alcohol. Taste is very bitter with a lot of sweetness at the end. Robust bodied, oily, with faint carbonation and a deep coffee character. Unexpected sweet finish, full of biscotti and coffee.

2016-08-27. Black body small brown head and lace. 3+ Aroma is an alcoholic melange of sweet dark malt, light roast and cocoa. Whisper of Hershey¬ís syrup. 7++ Flavour is rich, sweet dark malt, dry roast, finishes fairly bitter with roast coffee and hoppy bitterness. Draft sample at Logans Alley - pours jet black with light tan head . Nice lacing . Medium cocoa and vanilla aromas with a fair amount of bitter coffee . Taste brings similar notes with a smooth texture . Excellent !

Draft. Pours near black with a beige head. Rich and sweet mocha coffee, vanilla, mild-moderate roast, and creamy chocolate sweetness. A bit on the sweet side, but rich and delicious.

(On tap @ Mikkeller and Friends, Copenhagen, May 15 2016) Pours inky black with a small tan ring of head. Aroma is pungent earthy coffee, praline, chocolate cake, moderate roast, fairly dry, more brewed than bean character. Palate is fairly dry and long on earthy, chocolate-inflected coffee character. My notes are not the best but this is a top flight Speedway variant, dry and rich in flavours from the coffee chosen. Lovely stuff.

Pours an opaque black from the bomber with fluffy tan brown head that dissipates to leave moderate lace. Aroma of big roasty malts, awesome coffee, light roast cold press, hint of chocolate and cream. Taste is dead on to a Vietnamese coffee, cream and spice and light roast, amazing. On tap at the Upper West Side beer shop. Excellent brew! Superior to the regular Speedway imo. Rich malts, smoky, a little coffee and vanilla bean. Top of the line in every way.

Draft at Wheatberry. No idea this was available in Michigan. Description on the menu, which I should have photographed because the online link is broken, mentioned the Vietnamese coffee, so I¬ím putting my rating here. First of all, this was way too drinkable for 12% ABV, holy crap. Rich if not overly intense aromas of cocoa, coffee, and caramel (served a little colder than necessary, possibly muting some aromas). Full bodied, soft, rich and dessert like, finishing with lingering coffee bitterness. Really cool to have the opportunity to try this on draft in my neck of the woods. Fun experience, and a great coffee beer.

Bottle shared at the 8th Richmond Industry Gathering, 12/1/13. Pours a clear very dark brown color with a thin brown head. Fair head retention. Aroma of big chocolate notes, rich coffee, vanilla. The taste is raisin, chocolate, big coffee notes and an ashy finish. Medium bodied, slight warmth. Nice.

Bottle shared by the alum. Pours black with a thin brown head. Translucent brown at the edges. Low red apple notes. A bit ashy in the nose. Soft coffee, vanilla and roast. A bit fruity. On taste, creamy and a bit ashy in the finish. Moderate vanilla notes. Solid.

750ml bottle, thanks phaleslu for sharing! Very dark brown color. Good thin lighter brown head. Lots of dots of lace. Good complex coffee, dark chocolate in the nose... Wow, huge complex big coffee aroma in the flavor, much more there by the sip than the smell suggests. 2-3x more. Beyond your typical coffee beer. Some lighter lactose sugar. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, chewy texture. Lightly soft, smooth, lighter carbonation. More dry finish. Moderate to bigger bitter taste, light hint of acidity. Alcohol is superbly well hidden. Doesn¬ít even cross my mind until I see 12% on the label. Fantastic stuff. I¬íd love to sip a whole bottle this over the course of an evening.
750ml bottle - thanks Ryan for sharing! Poured a black color with an off white head. Nice coffee! Chocolate, vanilla, roast, and just all around goodness.

750ml bottle in a snifter. Pours black with a lacy, tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, some sweetness/milk, a good amount of chocolate, a little dough, and light bitterness. Flavor sort of dominated by the sweetness and lactose that isn¬ít there in other variations of Speedway Stout. Smooth, thicker texture. A really good beer, but this version is not as good as the others, especially the Kopi and Barrel Aged versions.

Bottle shared by phaleslu. Poured black color with an average frothy brown head that mostly lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavy roasted sweet coffee, chocolate and lactic aroma. Medium to abundant body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy roasted sweet flavor with a medium to heavy complex sweet finish of moderate to long duration. My high expectations where met with a solid drinkable beer.

750 ml bottle via trade. Bottled 8/5/13. Pours a deep, opaque brown with a small light brown head. Aroma of coffee, milk sugar, chocolate, earth, nuts, vanilla, cream, and hazelnut syrup. The flavor is pretty much the same- milk chocolate, coffee, cream, vanilla, and roasted malts. The lactose really balances the coffee here, something that was lacking in the regular Kopi Luwak one. Medium-full bodied, with moderate carbonation and a sweet, smooth mouthfeel. Very interesting, nice take on Speedway.

Bottle shared thanks to artmcd8. Poured a rich black with decent dark tan head. Aroma of deep roast coffee booze vanilla. As usual speedway fashion super smooth and oily. Drying slight bitter taste that lingers.

Pours a near black with a creamy looking brown head. Aroma of black coffee, fudge, and roasty chocolate. Tastes sweet with a light bitter finish. Very well balanced as always. Creamy mouthfeel. Medium to oily body and medium low carb.

Bottle shared by Al with Chevonne and I. Pours super oily mirror black with medium beige head that faded to a smaller ring, light lacing. Aromas and taste of milk chocolate, barrel, bitter coffee, vanilla bean, slow drip Vietnamese coffee flavor overall. Medium to fuller in body, very warming in upper chest. Unbelievable stout from Alesmith. Thanks for sharing brah.

Bottle. Pours black with a medium sized brown head. Nose and taste are both just a smooth, rich chocolate delight. Not significantly bitter. I¬ím not a coffe drinker, but this is one if the smoothest and well rounded coffe stouts I¬íve had. Mouthfeel stays full and doesn¬ít drop off like I¬íve seen in others. This one was great.

Bottle opened up at the 2013 year end Ottawa tasting, thanks Ian for bringing this. Black with a light brown head. Smooth, grated hazelnut (not overly sweet), slightly bitter chocolate, cashew, warming alcohol, creamy espresso. Mild+ carbonation and full body, easy to drink, warming coffee and chocolate with a nice roasted malt finish, becomes slightly dry with an alcoholic kick and a burst of sweetness on the finish. Very good beer.
Bottle from International Trade; dark brown pour with velvety tan head, earthy coffee aroma, taste has coffee, vanilla a hint of bitterness, chocolate, sweet, smooth tasting.

This was one of my favourite beers of a great night of tasting. Pours big rich espresso with a light brown covering. Nose is rich espresso and hazelnuts. Also notes of chocolate milk. Velvety in mouth. Awesome beer!
Bottle shared. Thanks Ben! Pours a dark brown to black with a beige head of foam. The aroma has coffee, vanilla, cream, and coconut. Tastes very roasty and creamy and sweet. Delicious beer. Wow!

A deep dark stout with a thin dark brown head. In aroma, bitter chocolate, roasted coffee and walnuts, with nice alcohol warmth. In mouth, nice smooth chocolate malt with coffee grind, hazelnuts, roasted character, oily mouth feel, very well balanced with alcohol warmth. Xmas Ottawa gathering Dec 13 2013.

Bottle... Poured jet black with a mild forming head. Aroma of roast and coffee. Nice coffee notes (seemed a bit more subtle than other speedway variants that I have had). Bitter-sweet molasses with a nice gingerbread cookie dough thing going on in the finish. Quite smooth.

Bottle from Douglas. Thanks! 

A: Perfect black color with a cappuccino head. Decent legs. 

N: Lots of coffee, caramel, and vanilla. Lots of smoked malt/espresso. Licorice.

T: Very chocoaltely with more of the coffee. Lots of smoke. Has notes of wood, though it isn¬ít barrel aged. 

M: Lots of alcoho. Thick, creamy, and oily. 

O: An interesting concoction with some clashing flavors. A bit astringent, as well. Not my favorite.

750 ml. bottle. Thanks Mike! Pours black with a decent reddish brown head. Aroma of malt, coffee, chocolate, and vanilla. Taste is roasted malt, milk chocolate, coffee, vanilla, lactose, and a touch of alcohol. Deserves it¬ís rating!

750 ml bottle. Pours a black oil can viscous mixture out with a creamy brown head. A big nose of milky coffee, some roast and chocolate. The flavor is dead on awesomeness: super sweet lactose and roasted coffee, vanilla, light fruit pushing through, some toffee and again more sweet full coffee. Great surprisingly mellow beer. Awesome. The palate alone is great, soft and full.

750mL bottle, sent from TigerBrew (thanks a lot, Cesar), pours black with a small brown head. Nose brings out loads of lactose sugar above anything, a little coffee, and a little roast. Flavour brings out loads of lactose sugar - this is a milk stout all out - with slight coffee, and a touch of roast. This is Speedway turned milk stout. Another amazing version of the classic Speedway.

Bottle for rating #5600: &nbsp Black, moderate foamy beige head, nice lacing. &nbsp Sweetened coffee up front, roasted malts, and a little spice. &nbsp Not sure what it is, but its nice. &nbsp Faint apple skin and lactose as well. &nbsp Roasty start, alcohol, soft coffee notes, but a little astringent. &nbsp Seems a bit young. &nbsp Smooth start, robust on the tongue. &nbsp Very warming. &nbsp Assertive coffee finish, roasty, with some heat. &nbsp Faint aspects of dark or bakers chocolate. &nbsp Very good beer, but seems a bit young and brash. &nbsp Needs a bit of smoothing out, but still very enjoyable.

Pours black with a small ring of bubbles. Aromas of tobacco, licorice, dark fruits, chocolate covered espresso beans and vanilla. Velvety smooth mouth feel with a somewhat dry finish. A wonderful beer!

Pours black, small tan head.

Smell lots of fruity licorice, dark chocolate

Tastebit nutty, sweet in middle, coco and bit of coffee roast, fruity

Mid body

Good
GABF 2013:. Pours a dark brown. Notes of chocolate and cofeee. Not much better than regular speedway

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2014 Bottle received in trade. Thank you nicks6217. Pours pitch black with a creamy goldenish greenish brown head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace on the glass. Smell is tiny sweet with roasted malts, dark roast coffee, raw coffee berries, banana bread, alcohol, high quality dark chocolate, chocolate chip cookies, coffee hard candy and hay. Taste is sweet, bitter, very tiny sour and malty with heavily roasted malts, dark roast coffee, banana bread, bitter chocolate, hay, soil, alcohol,  bitter chocolate truffles and hints if caramel and charred wood. Mouthfeel is round, creamy, silky, soft and full bodied. Finish is tiny sweet, bitter and malty with roasted malts, dark roast coffee, bitter chocolate, charred wood, chocolate milkshake, coffee hard candy, soil and hints of alcohol. A close to perfect beer. Big, fat, rich and very very complex. The coffee is perfectly balanced and the malts adds a very interesting bitter chocolate milkshake feel to the brew... I¬ím in awe!

(Bottle, thanks Alex!) Pours oily black with a perfect brown head. The aroma holds banana, wine gums, deep chocolate spicy fancy coffee, wet asphalt, wet stone, liquorice, earth, milk and and a touch of vanilla. Very balance and yummy on the nose. The flavour is light to medium sweet, medium bitter and tiny acidic. Notes of fruits, coffee, roasted malt, milk, roots and perfect hop profile. The mouthfeel is round, oily and fat with a perfect carbonation. Coffee, milk chocolate and hops on the finish. Near full bodied.

Bottle sent by my dear friend IBrew2or3. Cheers, Dave! Pours a deep stout brown color with a tan head. Nose is chocolate, chocolate syrup, milk chocolate, brownie, fudge, earth, some light roast, and some cafe con leche. Flavor is similar with huge chocolate, cocoa, chocolate, syrup, dark chocolate, and some light baker¬ís chocolate with some lactose, some sweetness, some cafe con leche, and slight roast. Medium in body and 12% of well-hidden alcohol, and some lingering coffee. An outstanding stout, a bit thinner in body than I¬íd like for something this big, but the nose and flavor are an absolute marvel.

This is one hell of a beer. Tons of lactose makes it come off very much like a rich alcoholic coffee milkshake. A bit of vanilla and tons of complex coffee notes dominate with a bit of chocolate and caramel. Wow this is fantastic.

Bottle. The pour is black with lacing that sticks around. The aroma is very nice. A great blend of the malt rich stout and the coffee, neither dominates in the nose at all. The taste is more of a stout and the coffee does not come through enough imo. A good drinking stout, but not all that much different that the base beer itself. Was expecting/hoping for more.

Bottle. Creamy black pour with beautiful tan foam. Aroma is quite unique, spicy, green coffee, cinnamon, maybe even a hint of chilies, cocoa. Taste is rich, sweet tasty Alesmith malt flavor signature yet well attenuated (not syrupy), spice, cinnamon, long mellow coffee finish with just a hint of alcohol heat. Palate is perfect, so rich and creamy, mouth-coating joy.

Bottle, sampled side-by-side with BA and Kopi. Compared with Kopi, the aroma is milkier -- milk chocolate and coffee. Taste: milk chocolatey goodness. Goddamn. This is fantastic. Smooth, milk chocolate, lots of vanilla, finishes with nice bitterness (more than Kopi). Winner of the night hands fucking down. Silky, velvety smooth sexiness here, full body, slick texture, smooth and awesome. So much milk chocolate, I love it. Holy wow. This beer is phenomenal, and absolutely blows its brothers out of the water. I¬ím honestly not a big fan of the speedways in general (as much as I¬íd like to be), but this may well be the single best imperial stout I¬íve ever had.
So smooth, first huge thanks to Justin! Big vanilla flavors, roasty coffee bitterness and big rich body, amazing stour

Bottle, thanks Alex! Pours dark brown/black, with a fairly large, brown head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, and lactose. Flavor is coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, hops, and alcohol. Heavy, smooth body, with a long finish.

Thanks BG! Pour is jet black, completly opaque. Nose is all chocolate. Nike breathing in a can of bakers chocolate. Taste is big chocolate notes, lots of roast a bit of coffee and some lactose sugar sweetness. You can taste the booze, but its like the booze in that cocca liquor. Its like an alcoholic mocha frappachino. Maybe a little too much chocolate bitterness on the back end but otherwise one of the best chocolate coffee stouts ive had.

Sampled at GABF. Exactly like regular speedway stout, but with a deeper roastiness from the coffee. The spice level is also expectedly amped up, with strong hints of cinnamon and nutmeg. While those spices are often used for Xmas and pumpkin beers, the heavy coffee flavor of this beer keeps them grounded in a non-seasonal profile. Good stuff. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sample at GABF - Actually stubled onto this one rather late in the day. Alesmith had a rather tucked away spot it seemed. Vanilla, with smooth mocha coffee, rich sweet chocolate. The lactose addition was certainly evident in the monthfeel. Rich decadent variant.

Nose is big coffee, vanilla, milk chocolate, ash. Taste is coffee, milk chocolate, ash. That ashiness present in Speedway stout variants is slightly off-putting to me but this was otherwise pretty awesome. The mouthfeel was thinner than regular Speedway. Still incredibly smooth, almost as if it had been barrel aged. Very impressive.

charred coffee, vanilla, worn leather and alcohol. Appearance: jet black body, beige and creamy head. Taste: mildly sweet cocoa, vanilla, bourbon give way to dark roasted and spicy floral coffee. Reminiscent of charbucks. Palate: surprisingly light body with creamy and soft mouthfeel. Finishes bitter but doesn¬ít linger too terribly long

As delicious as regular speedway stout, with one main difference: in the taste there is a spicier, floral note that I am guessing comes from the Viet coffee. Great stuff. Another homerun, AleSmith.

GABF 2013 
Aroma and flavors of roasted malts, rich roasted coffee and sweet chocolate 
Very nice, smooth.
Sampled at GABF 2013. Fairly similar to the regular stuff. Maybe a touch sweeter and the alcohol is little more prevalent. Still, damn good, but I prefer the OG.
GABF 2013. Lactose rounds the palate out really nicely compared to the regular, and the coffee is unique and very smooth.
Draft at GABF. Pours black with tan head. Nose and taste of rich chocolate, coffee, toasted nuts and light milk sugar. Full bodied.
Tap at GABF. Pours jet black. Sweet aroma. Big coffee nose. Very smooth and sweet and a bit of bitter coffee on the back end. Very nice beer and quite enjoyable.

Sample at GABF 2013. Pours near black with a medium beige head. Aroma is big roast,smooth coffee, milk chocolate, toffee and fudge. Flavour is light heavy sweet and bitter, alcohol noticeable in the finish. Full bodied with soft carbonation. Excellent, but would be better with a little age to smooth out the alcohol.

Sample @ GABF 13. Pitch black pour, thin layer of creamy beige head on top. Aroma is excellent. Roasted malts, coffee (kopi luwak?), licorice and booze. Flavour is intensely sweet, coffee returning big time. Some alcohol detected there, not disturbing at all. Smooth mouthfeel, goes down like silk. Epic brew, beer of the festival.

750ml bottle thanks to Darrell. Pours out black topped with a tan head. Aroma is great coffee sweet chocolate vanilla beans pit fruit and some spice.Taste is as the aroma with ccoffee leading the way. A great chocolate sweetness pit fruit vanilla and a little bitterness on the end. Awesome beer.

Bottle from Larry, nice coffee pour with light brown hues in the edge and a thin tan head that fades. Aroma is chocolate, coffee grounds, and the lactose is nice, get a bit of vanilla from it. Taste is rich coffee up front, creamy chocolate and lactose, nice bitter finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

October 6, 2013 - bottle shared by Brandon. Black pour with large tan head and lacing. Aroma was coffee, chocolate, vanilla and lactose. Taste was big time coffee, a little bit of the chocolate, vanilla and lactose was well. Finish was slightly bitter and dry alcohol.

75cl, new exclusive American brew Anno 2011, with coffee, thx to Secret Santa!, very complex Stout, roasted/bitter and slightly spicy/sweet, yet not too heavy, balanced, hazy, small head, very good brew, yet very expensive!

750ml bottle pours a thick black with some sudsy, brown head. Nose is interesting, some nail polish, coffee grounds, Kahlua, a little dark chocolate. Flavor is sweet, brown sugar, malt, some lacto sugar, molasses, Kahlua, coffee grounds, black pepper. Peppery finish.

black with large bubbled cream head that lasts. Stinging grinds in the nose, sweet and green. Flavor improves drastically, rich coffee all over before the creamy oats and chocolate in the finish. Bitterness builds with warmth, very balanced.

75cl bottle, thanks noodleuser. Small brown head atop clear dark brown body. Aroma is moderately sweet, bittersweet chocolate, some coffee, light frosting. Taste is milk/bittersweet chocolate, some coffee, light frosting. Medium-full body, some stickiness.

Bottle shared by noodleuser. Pours opaque black with a small, fizzy tan head, short retention with light lacing. Aroma is chocolate, cookie and roast malt, lactose, prunes and vanilla. Flavor is dark malt dominant, light alcohol, vanilla, dark fruits, light hops and bitterness with a dry finish. Full body and medium carbonation.

Bottle, thanks to noodleuser! Poured a pitch black color with some ruby edges. Aroma is chocolate, notes of coffee, roast malts. Flavor is so smooth, great chocolate and roasted character. Quite good!

Bottle @ Steve¬ís house, courtesy of Steve. Thanks! Pours a black appearance with a nice dark brown head. Big vanilla, coffee, dark chocolate, somewhat sweet, balanced coffee aroma. Earthy, dark chocolate, vanilla, milk shake, light woody, rich coffee flavor. Nice!

Pour out of 750 mL bottle, big thanks to Steve for the pour. Thick black pour with tan head, aroma brought notes of big dark chocolate, vanilla, lots of caramel, hints of milk, lactose, slight earth, spice. Taste is a mix of dark chocolate, nice coffee, milk, hints of lactose, earth, hints of oak, slight vanilla, finishing bitter, dry.
Sample from a bottle. From notes. Loads of coffee with milk and dark chocolate and a hint of dark fermented fruit. Awesome.
Bottle shared during the Foothills BA Sexual Chocolate release. Loads of marshmallow, toasted coconut, and warming alcohol to go with great coffee and liquid chocolate flavor. Supoib!

On tap @ AleSmith. Obsidian pour with a dark mahogany edge and a chestnut foam. Loads of Starbucks, roasted Kona beans dipped in Godiva chocolate, raisin, vanilla, and toasted oats. The alcohol is virtually invisible and the mouthfeel is thick, coating, and velvety. Another one that confirms that AleSmith is my favorite brewery!

On tap at brewery. Black with a creamy tan head. Strong roasty dark chocolate and espresso aroma and taste with a dry bitter finish and a cinnamon like spice and citrus notes hiding in the background. Thick sticky full bodied palate.

UPDATED: JAN 5, 2014 Revisited: On tap @ Alesmith. Pours deep black like motor oil with a nice mocha head. Aroma is coffee, coffee, coffee! Also chocolate, dark fruit¬Öthink figs, plums and raisins, toasted malts and more coffee. Taste of this one is big coffee, chocolate, dark fruits, and more coffee. Simply an amazing stout! Full bodied, creamy mouthful, delicious nectar! This is simply perfection.

Super dark black oily color with a thin brown film of bubbles and lacing left behind. Aroma was hugely coffee-based, with dark dried figs, plums, cherries, chocolate, hazelnut, toasty grains, and of course EtOH! Hey, it¬ís super strong, what do you expect? It fits nicely into the heavy duty overall profile of this beer and so you won¬ít notice that you¬íve been gulping. But you¬íll be feeling it! A great beer, nice subtle variant of the classic Speedway. I¬íll keep trying these variations because they are bold, yet subtle and interesting... gotta get that one with civet poop coffee... next time!

Beautiful appearance: copious dark brown head atop the black body. Nose is a bit oxidized, coffee fades with the head (slowly). Lactic aroma. And boozy. Heavy coffee profile; warmth and chocolate join the fray. Needs a tad more body. Did I mention it's boozy? A bit underwhelming overall.

Bottle at my place with group. Pours suit black with light lacing that lasts. Aroma is insanity good, creamy, coffee, medical cardboard. Taste is chocolate malt mild coffee, vegetable. Finish is long malt chocolaty . Very nice beer
Pours black with tan head and nice lacing. Aroma of dark malts, coffee, and soy sauce. Taste is burnt malts, brown sugar, coffee, and booze. Wow. Great beer.

Poured a black color from a growler, huge chocolate, coffee, milk chocolate, and earth aromas, man does this smell amazing. Flavors are the same, fresh pressed cold coffee with chocolate milk and light vanilla, holy smokes was this beer good.

Taster at the brewery.
Aroma is full of rich creamy coffee with hints of vanilla, chocolate and roast. As it warns there is a faint hint of alcohol heat. I¬ím amazed how creamy this is without adding lactose. 
Pour is black with a slightly thin tan head that recedes fairly quickly. No lacing and moderate legs. 
Flavor is full of rich chocolate with really nice coffee character. The coffee is really creamy and is not vegetal at all. Alcohol more apparent as it warms with some light bitterness. Lingering alcohol, coffee and chocolate.
Mouthfeel is medium full bodied with medium low carbonation. Very low astringency, somewhat surprising considering the style of beer. Low alcohol warmth.
Overall an amazingly enjoyable coffee stout. Most likely my favorite coffee stout I have tried. The coffee is so rich and creamy without being astringent, vegetal or green. This beer is what other coffee stouts should strive for.

750ml bottle courtesy of Tim. thanks, man! pours just a bit richer and denser than the base Speedway with a creamy, thick mocha head that leaves rich sheets of lace. aroma is simply outstanding with rich, bitter coffee, burnt grinds, sweet lactose sugar, cocoa powder, and milk chocolate with hints of vanilla, coconut cr√®me, and almonds as it warms. flavor is just marvelous as well with rich milk chocolate, cake batter, mousse, and sweet chocolate milkshake backed by dense, rich, herbal coffee with perfect bitterness, some light, floral fruits, vanilla icing, and a touch of hazelnut on the back end. palate is rich, creamy, and wonderfully dense (by far the richest of the Speedway variants) with smooth carbonation and a lingering finish of bitter coffee. overall, just another excellent effort from Alesmith.

cask - knb wine 5th anny. pitch black no head. Strong coffee aroma. A little thinner body then I remember from the std Speedway but it¬ís been awhile. Taste is delicious, milky coffee with just a slight bitter finish. Chocolatey and sweet.
A quick pour at the ba buffalo bottle share. Just enough to tick, dark chocolate, roasted coffee, and some vanilla. Full thick body. Can¬ít wait till the bottle from tleaver.

Ale smith vietnamese speedway stout. Pours pitch black with a reamy tanned head. Aroma is fullbodied sweet coffee cho olate some vanilla tones dark fruits. Fla or as fullbodied as aroma, very fruity a bit acidy good roastiness and pleasant longlived bitterness.

Bottle, 08/29/2013. Pours black, large tan head fades to rest hazy on the surface, dense lacing left around the glass. Aroma is fluffy chocolate mousse, dark fruits, vanilla and dark roast, mildly sweet milky coffee finish, rich. Taste is creamy milk chocolate, powdered vanilla, rich earthy coffee and fruity roast, subtle berries, moderate bitterness. Thick body, smooth, well balanced. Great.

Tap at Craftsman Table & Tap. Quite viscous pour, tar black with espresso head. Differences from normal Speedway are immediately apparent: spicy, fruity coffee nose, with loads of dark chocolate. Less of that black coffee acidity. Iced, creamy coffee up front, and chocolate for days on the end. A little blackberry to boot. Another level.

On tap at Craftsman Table and Tap - Pours black with a thin tan head. Nose is a bit sharp, with some bourbony booziness, sweet dark malt, toffee, and caramel. Taste is very different. It¬ís almost a caramel milk stout with some smooth dark roast coffee on the finish. Sweet but not cloying with a milky coffee finish. Smooth and slick like a milkshake. Yum.
Bottle at RBSG. Pours black with thin head. Tons of roasted malts and coffee on the nose. Thick and chocolatey, with coffee owning the taste.
Pours black brown tight thin khaki head leaves thin collar. Aroma has roasted chocolate malt fruity coffee. Taste is bitter fruity with chocolate coffee and warming. Palate is full slick and dry.

Cask at the Blue Palms Brewhouse 5th Anniversary. Aroma of cocoa, earthy coffee, touch of anise; the spices take over the nose late. Pours jet black with a perfectly even khaki head. Deep roasted malt flavor hits early on the taste before chocolate and the spicy Vietnamese coffee blend kicks in with hints of allspice, woody tannins, rich loamy dirt, and cinnamon. The heat grows but never overpowers the palate. Nice, but not my favorite Speedway variant.
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Bomber at RBSG. Deep brown pour with a medium head. Very rich coffee - somewhat bitter. Very good!
Bottle shared by biglobo! Dark black pour, little carbonation and an aroma of coffee and sweet milk. Flavor is very bitter espresso, dry and nice and sweet on the finish.

On tap at AleSmiths tasting room.
Motor oil black with a moderate but resiliant tan head. Aroma= Coffee Coffee And Coffee. But good coffee. The taste is fantastic. You definitely taste the coffee but backrounds of cocao, caramel and supreme maltiness. the mouthfeel is silky. Easily one of the best beers I have had.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2015 Draught @ CBC 2015, Yellow Session, K√∏benhavn
Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, caramel, alcohol and cocoa. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and medium bitter with a long warm, roasted, coffee, chocolate and cocoa finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.
Cask @ AleSmith Brewing Company, San Diego, CA
Pours pitch black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, licorice and alcohol. Taste is medium to heavy sweet and medium bitter with a long warm, sweet coffee and licorice finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is flat. [8 4 8 5 16 = 4.1 8/14/2013]

Cask at the taproom. Press black with a beige head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, nuts, roasted malt and caramel. Flavor sweet coffee with some chocolate, warming alcohol, roasted grains and caramel. Full body, soft carbonation.

On tap at the taproom. A next to black beer, topped by a dense, two-finger tan head. Lots of coffee on the nose, dark chocolate, some hoppy scents and alcohol. Lots of coffee in the flavor, as well as dark chocolate, bitterness and roasted malts. Quite sweet, full bodied and warming. Nice carbonation. Long finish. Quite lovely. 130814

Draft at The Malt House in Madison, WI celebrating their release to the WI market. Damn, thick, black, tan head. Big coffee nose, vanilla, toffee, bitter chocolate. All the nose is again in the taste, with some nice heat from the high ABV. Very nice!

Growler filled last week, pill-bottle slightly leaky enjoyed in a tulip at 55F

A -  Almost midnight black, Nice 1 finger brown head that fades slowly to a nice rack of lacing.

S - Roasted milk chocolate, very earthy - nutty aroma of old espresso beans. Not bright and fruity, just earthy, dark, malty and big aroma of a latte that¬ís sat out for a few hours but still smells nice. It may just be the Vietnamese coffee is not bright like latin american or african beans are

T -  Well, it¬ís most certainly a speedway stout. Big chocolate and roasted coconut along with some vanilla. The coffee is good but it¬ís very old, tannic, acidic, bitter and sort of like cough syrup in the middle and finish. This alone is a turn off. Everything else about speedway really shines but the coffee used in this actually takes away from a great stout.

M - Heavy body, low carbonation (of course due to leakage). Dry and stringent boozy finish.

O - It¬ís easy to get caught up in hype and the fact I¬ím reviewing this as it¬ís currently #50 on the top beers list for RateBeer. Don¬ít misunderstand, it¬ís a great tasting stout but it¬ís not a top 50 stout. A solid 4 but I just can¬ít rate it higher and it could be the coffee type used but it is a coffee stout so I guess that¬ís part of the problem. Coffee bean taste profiles are like beer...coffee geeks love a certain bean and hate the other and this one just doesn¬ít work for me.

Pill bottle growler that Adam Jackson got in a recent trade, thanks bud! Pitch black color light, thin tan head. Nose is serious Earthy coffee. Taste  is earthy, dirty coffee, bitter chocolate, nutty peanut skins and a finish of thick chocolate syrup. The ABV does show up a bit more then I want. In fact I know the growler lost some carbonation but the mouthfeel is heavy on the alcohol which detracts from the nice coffee flavors. Lots of lactose sugar notes. The brewer tried to recreate a Vietnamese Iced Coffee taste, I understand what the brewers vision is. Really sweet coffee with cream. It¬ís really good but I have had better coffee Impy stouts.

Growler, thanks Alex!

Pours black, very subtle mocha-colored head, thin ring.  Notes of coffee, chocolate, light vanilla, toffee...much more coffee-forward then the regular speedway.  Flavor is coffee up front, milk chocolate, smooth booze for 12%.  Mouthfeel is light carbonation, rich & creamy finish.  Good stuff!

Poured into a snifter from a 32 oz. growler. Huge thanks to anotherjoe for this.

4.5 A: Black color. Two fingers of mainly cream, minorly frothy tan head. Retention is pretty good given the ABV and plenty of lacing is left, which is impressive given the coffee.

5.0 S: This smells amazing. I can¬ít really remember what the regular Speedway smells like at the moment, but I¬ím just going to say that this is different and better. The coffee is sweeter and more chocolatety. Supple roast, caramel, light molasses, chocolate, sweet neutral maltiness. Big pithy coconut, vanilla, and a lactose-like creaminess. 

4.5 T: Tastes mainly like the nose, but isn¬ít quite as powerful and impressive. Chocolate, roastiness, neutral maltiness, caramel, molasses, coconut, lactose, coconut, vanilla. Coffee is tangy, super smooth, chocolatety, and wonderfully roasty. Quite tasty.

4.0 M: Heavier medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Super smooth and goes down incredibly easy. My only complaint is that it¬ís not quite creamy enough. Still good here though.

4.5 D: Definitely a winner. I love the original Speedway, but wasn¬ít impressed with the barrel aged version, but now I¬ím all about trying variants of this again.

On tap at the brewery, served in a tasting glass. Pours deep black with a medium brown head that mostly remains and laces well. The nose has huge notes of coffee and roasted malts, along with smoke, dark chocolate, tobacco and a touch of earth. The flavour is fairly dry and moderately bitter with huge coffee and hints of chocolate, herbs and moderate hoppy bitterness. The finish is long and bitter with roasted coffee, dark chocolate and roasted malts. On the palate, it is full in body with a dryish texture and average carbonation.
